none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from Henry Alvord, March 8, 1894
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from Henry Alvord, March 8, 1894
Box 2 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 2 Folder 11 Louis L. McInnis Papers

| | | | | :--- | :---: | :--- | | **OFFICERS, 1893-94.**

PRESIDENT.
Gen. STEPHEN D. LEE,
President, Miss. Agr'l and Mech'l College,
Agricultural College (P. O.),
Mississippi.

VICE-PRESIDENTS.
JAMES H. CANFIELD, M. A.,
Chancellor, University of Nebraska,
Lincoln, Neb.
WILLIAM FREAR, Ph. D.,
Vice Director, Agricultural Exp't Station,
State College, Penn.
HIRAM HADLEY, M. A.,
Pres., N. M. College of Agr. and Mech. Arts,
Director, Agricultural Exp't Station,
Las Cruces, New Mexico.
GEORGE E. MORROW, M. A.,
Prof. of Agriculture, Univ of Illinois,
Champaign, Ill.
JAMES S. NEWMAN,
Director, So. Car. Agricultural Exp't Station,
Fort Hill, South Carolina.

SECRETARY AND TREASURER.
M. A. SCOVELL, M. S.,
Director, Kentucky Agricultural Exp't Station,
Lexington, Ky. | **ASSOCIATION**
OF
American Agricultural Colleges
AND
Experiment Stations.








OFFICE OF EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE,
No. 932 New York Avenue.
**WASHINGTON, D. C.** | **EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE,
1893-94.**

Maj. HENRY E. ALVORD, CHAIRMAN,
Lewinsville, Fairfax Co., Virginia,
or, Washington, D. C.
HENRY H. GOODELL, LL.D.,
President, Massachusetts Agricultural College,
Director, Hatch Experiment Station,
Amherst, Mass.
A. W. HARRIS, M. A.,
President, Maine State College,
Orono, Me.
WM. A. HENRY, B. Ag.,
Dean, College of Agr., Univ. of Wis.,
Director of Agricultural Exp't Station,
Madison, Wis.
HENRY C. WHITE, Ph. D.,
Pres., Ga. State College Agr. and Mech. Arts,
Athens, Ga.
The PRESIDENT and the SECRETARY
of the Association, ex-officio.

BIBLIOGRAPHER.
SAM'L W. JOHNSON, M. A.,
Director, Conn. Agr'l Experiment Station,
New Haven, Conn. |

L. L. McInnis Esq.
Bryan, Texas.

March 8th 1894.

Dear Sir:- Altho' you could have had very little personal interest in the matter,
it would have been courtesy on my part, to have informed you, in the Summer of 1892
of the result of the Maryland College controversy, in which your former acquain-
tance Brunk figured, - and in connection with which you so kindly aided me.

The said marplot apparently repeated his Texan operations, with some
variations - but no improvements. He got just one member of our Faculty to
join him - and I was forced to make an issue with those two. All others of the
Faculty - and every member of our (over-large) Board of Trustees who had served two
years or more with me, - stood solidly by me. Brunk took advantage of the
incoming of a new element in the Board, - strong partisans, too, - anxious to find
- or to make, - places for their friends. So Brunk + Hird (his partner) got an
official following, who made them an excuse for the cry that there was
lack of harmony in the Faculty, - and that a general re-organization was needed.

I had such strong backing, however, that the friends of Brunk (or those so
appearing) came to me, and offered to compromise + re-elect me + the entire
Faculty, if I would withdraw my charges agt. Brunk and Hird. This I
positively declined, - and Brunk and Hird were then dropped. My
re-election was postponed - and I "held over" some months. But those two

**Analysis and Transcription of a Letterhead and Handwritten Letter** Alright, let's get down to brass tacks. I've got an image in front of me, and my job is to extract the text. This isn't just about mechanically copying characters; it's about understanding the *structure* and the intent behind it. This letterhead, "ASSOCIATION OF American Agricultural Colleges AND Experiment Stations," is the first piece. My initial approach is to break it down into logical blocks. The letterhead is arranged in three columns, each containing specific information. On the left, we've got the "OFFICERS, 1893-94" – President, Vice-Presidents, and the Secretary/Treasurer. Then in the center, the prominent title of the association and the address. On the right is the "EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE, 1893-94." It appears someone made a red "X" through the right column, but for the purpose of the transcription, I'll focus on the text itself unless instructed otherwise. I can make a markdown table for this three-column layout. The central header is quite dominant, the columns are secondary. Here's the data, organized. I'll include the subtle font variations – small caps, etc. I'll maintain the original line breaks for clarity: | OFFICERS, 1893-94. | ASSOCIATION
OF
American Agricultural Colleges
AND
Experiment Stations. | EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE,
1893-94. | | :------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :--------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | PRESIDENT.
Gen. STEPHEN D. LEE,
President, Miss. Agr'l and Mech'l College,
Agricultural College (P. O.),
Mississippi. | OFFICE OF EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE,
No. 932 New York Avenue.
WASHINGTON, D. C. | Maj. HENRY E. ALVORD, CHAIRMAN,
Lewinsville, Fairfax Co., Virginia,
or, Washington, D. C. | | VICE-PRESIDENTS.
JAMES H. CANFIELD, M. A.,
Chancellor, University of Nebraska,
Lincoln, Neb. | | HENRY H. GOODELL, LL.D.,
President, Massachusetts Agricultural College,
Director, Hatch Experiment Station,
Amherst, Mass. | | WILLIAM FREAR, Ph. D.,

State College, Penn. | | A. W. HARRIS, M. A.,
President, Maine State College,
Orono, Me. | | HIRAM HADLEY, M. A.,
Pres., N. M. College of Agr. and Mech. Arts,
Director, Agricultural Exp't Station,
Las Cruces, New Mexico. | | WM. A. HENRY, B. Ag.,
Dean, College of Agr., Univ. of Wis.,
Director of Agricultural Exp't Station,
Madison, Wis. | | GEORGE E. MORROW, M. A.,
Prof. of Agriculture, Univ of Illinois,
Champaign, Ill. | | HENRY C. WHITE, Ph. D.,
Pres., Ga. State College Agr. and Mech. Arts,
Athens, Ga.
The PRESIDENT and the SECRETARY
of the Association, ex-officio. | | JAMES S. NEWMAN,
Director, So. Car. Agricultural Exp't Station,
Fort Hill, South Carolina. | | BIBLIOGRAPHER.
SAM'L W. JOHNSON, M. A.,
Director, Conn. Agr'l Experiment Station,
New Haven, Conn. | | SECRETARY AND TREASURER.
M. A. SCOVELL, M. S.,
Director, Kentucky Agricultural Exp't Station,
Lexington, Ky. | | | Now, the

vacancies did not satisfy the new Board. They wanted three more and
moved agt. three professors who had loyally stood by me, & the good work
of the College. I did the only fair thing, - and stood by them, - a long
contest followed, - and finally we all went out together.

Brother Brunk has been wandering, since. I have heard of him in
Illinois and Indiana, - he started a little "College" of his own somewhere
in the Indiana swamps, - but was disappointed in its endowment, -
owing to the hard times (! - ?) - and it lived only a few weeks.

Last year, - I was fully employed in looking out for the Collective
College & Station Exhibit at Chicago, - was there till December.

Now, this Winter, - I have agreed to remain here, - (I live but 10 miles out, -)
and watch the interests of the Assn. There are some points in prospective
legislation by Congress, giving a little anxiety, - but all will come out right.

By early Summer, - I shall be foot-free, - hence I am already on the
lookout for occupation. Naturally, I prefer something in the line wh. I
have been following for twenty years or more, - should an opening occur.

Indirectly, I have heard that a new president of the Texas College
might soon be wanted, - altho' why - or just when, I have not learned.
Can you tell me anything on this point? If there is to be a vacancy,
do you think it would be worth while for me to become a candidate?
I think that with time and opportunity, - I can make up a strong case.

Who constitute the present Board? - and are they men to be approached
purely on the qualifications basis, - or with some political influence added?

I shall highly appreciate a reply.

Hoping you are in good health & with personal regards - I am -
Yours very truly - Henry E. Alvord.

**Transcribing a Handwritten Letter: A Thought Process** Alright, let's get down to business. First, I need to understand what's being asked of me. My task is straightforward: transcribe the text from this image of a handwritten letter. I'm operating as a professional transcriptionist, so I'll need to maintain the original spelling, punctuation, capitalization, and layout – including line breaks. Any illegible text will be marked as such. The only HTML tags allowed are the approved ones. Now, let's analyze the image itself. It's a handwritten letter, which immediately tells me I'll be dealing with cursive and stylistic variations. The content is key: Henry E. Alvord is discussing his professional history, specifically his departure from a college and his current work situation. He's also inquiring about a potential presidency at the Texas College. The letter appears to be structured in paragraphs, with a standard closing and signature. My process will be methodical. I'll read the text line by line, paying close attention to every detail. For example, in the first paragraph, I see "agt." which is likely an abbreviation for "against," and the ampersand is distinct. The dashes are also important for the flow. I need to retain these minor variations. In the second paragraph, I'll need to recognize "Brother Brunk" as a proper name. The quotation marks around "College" are deliberate. The strange punctuation "(! - ?)" also needs to be transcribed accurately. The third paragraph mentions the "Collective College & Station Exhibit," which seems to be a specific entity from a World's Fair. Proper nouns must be preserved. In the fourth, the abbreviation "Assn." for "Association" should be correctly transcribed, as well as the use of parentheses. The fifth paragraph has a hyphenated word, "foot-free," and the abbreviation "wh." for "which" – all details I need to capture. The sixth is particularly interesting, as I need to be careful with "Texas College," and the apostrophe in "altho'." There's also a crossed-out letter in what should be "think," but I'm confident in the intended word. The line break in the layout and the context confirms this. The seventh is standard cursive, and the eighth is a simple sentence. Finally, I reach the closing and signature. I'll need to preserve the formatting here, including the line break before "Yours very truly - Henry E. Alvord." I'll be careful to wrap each paragraph in `

` tags. The prompt explicitly requests to "Preserve... line breaks", so I need to insert `
` at the end of each physical line within each paragraph to accurately represent the original layout. I'll check against the image, double-checking for consistency and accuracy. Then, finally, I'll assemble the final output using the correct tags. And then it's done. The final result is just the transcribed text.
